name: maize grain processing, dry milling | maize chop | Cutoff, U
description:
ecoQuery: https://ecoquery.ecoinvent.org/3.10/cutoff/dataset/21570/documentation

This dataset represents the production of 1 kg of maize flour, as well as the secondary products maize chop and maize screenings from global dry milling practices. Maize flour (or corn meal) is a common staple food made from maize ground to different consistencies of fine, medium or coarse. In this dataset maize flour represents all grades of maize meal (sifted, super, special, unsifted etc.), maize rice, maize grits and other products, all intended for human consumption. The secondary products are intended for use in animal feed as an energy and/or protein source, particularly in beef production. The module includes the receiving of maize and processing thereof through multiple cleaning, grinding and sieving steps. Activities that have been considered in this dataset are the inputs of maize, water, electricity, land, infrastructure and an output of waste water.;Boundary of exchanges for maize grain processing by dry milling

This activity starts with the maize received at the gate of the dry milling plant. Maize received is weighed on weighbridges before entering the plant. Stones, sand, sticks, etc. contained in the maize are removed during the initial cleaning process step. 

This activity ends with the delivery of 1 kg of maize flour, along with by-product(s), at the factory gate of the dry milling plant.
category: C:Manufacturing/10:Manufacture of food products/106:Manufacture of grain mill products, starches and starch products/1061:Manufacture of grain mill products

processDocumentation.timeDescription: The production data represented in this dataset are based on International Grain Council (IGC) supply and demand data for the 2016/2017 marketing season retrieved online. Reference(s): IGC (2017) Market Information - Supply and Demand, International Grain Council, Available at: https://www.igc.int/en/markets/marketinfo-sd.aspx. (Accessed November 2017); IGC (2014) Five-Year Global Supply and Demand Projections, International Grain Council, Available at: http://www.igc.int/en/downloads/grainsupdate/igc_5yrprojections2014.pdf. (Accessed November 2017).
processDocumentation.geographyDescription: The inventory is based on calculations made for South Africa.
processDocumentation.technologyDescription: The data are intended to reflect current equipment and processes.
processDocumentation.samplingDescription: Extrapolated from South African data, uncertainty adjusted accordingly.

exchanges.description: This figure is based on the annual average output of products from dry milling for human consumption in South Africa reported by SAGIS (South African Grain Information Service) on a monthly basis (July 2015 - June 2016). Maize processed for human consumption refers to dry milling for the production of samp, maize meal, rice, grits and other products for human consumption, and a hominy chop by-product sold into the animal feed industry. Reference(s): SAGIS (2016) Maize Products per Month Manufactured - July 2015 to June 2016, South African Grain Information Service. Available at: www.sagis.org.za. (Accessed April 2017)

flow.name: maize chop
flow.category: C:Manufacturing/10:Manufacture of food products/106:Manufacture of grain mill products, starches and starch products/1061:Manufacture of grain mill products

exchanges.description:
Average electricity use of two dry milling facilities in South Africa: 26 kWh/tonne based on annual production data of a combined wheat & maize mill, and 86 kWh/tonne based on hourly production data of a dedicated maize mill.
EcoSpold01Location=CH

exchanges.description: Estimate from industrial machinery used in "Limestone, crushed, for mill production" (annual production of 195,000 tonnes), which is assumed to provide a good proxy for flour milling. Value adapted on the basis of annual production, which was estimated to be an average of 415,000 tonnes per year, based on the production figures of two dry milling facilities in South Africa. The estimated life span of the machines is 25 years.

exchanges.description: This figure represents maize received at the gate of the dry milling plant to produce 1 kg milled maize products. An average of 6% of maize received is estimated to be reject material (foreign matter and defective kernels), representative of a high grade of maize. Maize received is weighed on weighbridges before entering the plant and contains stones, sand, sticks, etc. which are removed during the initial cleaning process step. Maximum permissable levels of deviations depend on the grade of maize, and range from 8% to 30%, this includes foreign matter (with max permissable levels ranging from 0.3%-0.75%) and defective maize kernels. Quality sampling over the period 2001/02 - 2010/11 suggests the majority of maize produced falls within the standard, with a weighted average of 6.2% total deviations over this period (with a weighted average foreign matter of 0.2%). References: Department of Agriculture (2009). Regulations relating to the grading, packing and marking of maize intended for sale in the Republic of South Africa. Government gazette, 8 May 2009; Southern African Grain Laboratory (SAGL) (2011) South African Maize Crop Quality Report 2010/2011 Season.

exchanges.description: Estimation. Not geography specific. Value scaled to reference product. Comment from "maize grain, feed production, GLO": The typical storage capacity of the cereal silo found in some feed processing centres in Switzerland is 10,000 tonnes, with an effective storage volume of about 80% of the building volume. With an average grain specific weight of 750 kg/m3, this gives a building volume of about 16,650 m3. Assuming that these feed processing centres process 25,000 tonnes of grain per year, the cereals will be stored for about three months before being processed. The largest feed processing centre in Switzerland (UFA-Biblis) has a feedstuff storage compound of 29,440 m3 (80 m length * 23 m * 16 m height) with an effective storage capacity of 4,140 tonnes (5520 palettes of 750 kg), or about 150 kg/m3 (UFA 2002). This centre processes 275,000 tonnes of concentrate feeds yearly. After processing, the feedstuff must therefore be stored for approx. one week in the processing centre before being sent to the regional storehouse. The average length of storage of the raw materials is set at 3 months in the calculations. The storage volume required was estimated as 1.7 m3/tonne of raw material (grain specific weight 750 kg/m3 and 80% of the building volume used for storage). The lifetime of the storage silo was assumed to be 50 years, the length of the construction phase 2 years. Land use was estimated from the height of Bibliss storage silo (UFA 2002). Taking the height of 16 m, the area used is 0.1 m2/tonne of feedstuff for 3 months.

exchanges.description: Estimate, not geography specific. Water is used to clean the maize received ( to remove stones, sand, sticks, etc. picked up from the field during the harvesting of the maize and during storage) and to increase the moisture content of the grain. The water does not contain any chemicals, only minor impurities from the washing process, and is thus considered to be unpolluted. The waste water is released to the municipal sewage system, without prior treatment, based on information provided by two South African mills. The estimate that 32% of water input is consumptive is from literature for a European mill: Salzgeber & Lrcher (1996), cited in "maize grain, feed production, GLO".

exchanges.description: Estimate from industrial machinery used in "Limestone, crushed, for mill production" (annual production of 195,000 tonnes), which is assumed to provide a good proxy for flour milling. Value adapted on the basis of annual production, which was estimated to be an average of 415,000 tonnes per year, based on the production figures of two dry milling facilities in South Africa. The estimated life span of the machines is 25 years.

Water is used to clean the maize received ( to remove stones, sand, sticks, etc. picked up from the field during the harvesting of the maize and during storage) and to increase the moisture content of the grain. The water does not contain any chemicals, only minor impurities from the washing process, and is thus considered to be unpolluted. The waste water is released to the municipal sewage system, without prior treatment, based on information provided by two South African mills. exchanges.description: This figure represents maize received at the gate of the dry milling plant to produce 1 kg milled maize products. An average of 6% of maize received is estimated to be reject material (foreign matter and defective kernels), representative of a high grade of maize. Maize received is weighed on weighbridges before entering the plant and contains stones, sand, sticks, etc. which are removed during the initial cleaning process step. Maximum permissable levels of deviations depend on the grade of maize, and range from 8% to 30%, this includes foreign matter (with max permissable levels ranging from 0.3%-0.75%) and defective maize kernels. Quality sampling over the period 2001/02 - 2010/11 suggests the majority of maize produced falls within the standard, with a weighted average of 6.2% total deviations over this period (with a weighted average foreign matter of 0.2%). References: Department of Agriculture (2009). Regulations relating to the grading, packing and marking of maize intended for sale in the Republic of South Africa. Government gazette, 8 May 2009; Southern African Grain Laboratory (SAGL) (2011) South African Maize Crop Quality Report 2010/2011 Season.
